author: treyzania
content: That's a common misconception, smart contracts are not necessarily a contract between a defined set of parties

author: treyzania
content: The evm bytecode you get from that block explorer *is* the official contract

author: zkdid
content: Yes I see what your saying, so there is only a contract with a  protocol, is that correct?

author: treyzania
content: the contract is some state with code that you can interact with on a distributed ledger, it's not "with" something in the traditional sense

author: zkdid
content: does the person who transferred the ETH have a contract with the state of the code, or is the person not part of the contract at all, it's weird question i know, I am talking about the node validation deposit contract

author: treyzania
content: you're talking about the eth2 deposit contract right?

author: zkdid
content: yes

author: treyzania
content: the better way to think about contracts is like objects in an OO language, except each object lives in a separate security domain and communicate exclusively through message passing

author: treyzania
content: when the deposit contract is entered by the vm interpreter it asserts that the ether balance sent along with the message is >= 32 ETH, and if it does then updates some internal counters and the current deposits root, and emits a log entry that announces the new validator registration

author: treyzania
content: now that alone is meaningless, unless you include the eth1_data mechanism from the beacon chain protocol as part of the larger cryptographic system, and assign ether balances in that with the same notion of real-world "value" that the ether deposited into the contract does

author: treyzania
content: but that's completely a social construct, you have to count eth2 as also really ethereum for it to mean anything

author: zkdid
content:
I understand you and am grateful for the explanation. I am trying to find an explanation in laymen terms to distinguish where I stand with the protocol and smart contract. My understanding is User>Money>ETH>Transfer>Protocol>Contract>User.

my point is, if my contract is with a protocol, there is still a contract between me a physical person and a Protocol, whether it is physical entity or digital entity the contract is between two parties

author: pietjepuk
content: It's not a contract though, you just call some function

author: treyzania
content: The contract is not between anything, it's a mechanism in a cryptographic system

author: zkdid
content: Its called ETH Deposit Contract

author: pietjepuk
content: Smart contracts are a terrible name for what they actually are

author: zkdid
content: and right here there is a tab that says "contract"

author: pietjepuk
content: But that's just what they're called

author: zkdid
content: https://etherscan.io/address/0x00000000219ab540356cbb839cbe05303d7705fa#code

author: treyzania
content: smart contracts *are not* legal contracts

author: zkdid
content: would you be so kind as to elaborate, thats a bit weird

author: treyzania
content: they're like objects (data with associated code) in an oo language runtime like the jvm

author: treyzania
content: that's why solidity feels a lot like java in a lot of ways, as much as java itself sucks

author: zkdid
content: A bit strange they are names contracts, and a bit misleading

author: treyzania
content: Language is whatever we decide it is and the term "smart contract" predates cryptocurrencies

author: zkdid
content: I dont mean to be rude, so please excuse me but would language not be expressed as defined by something, a contract is a legal term

author: pietjepuk
content: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_contract

author: pietjepuk
content: Check the etymology section

author: treyzania
content: If you're a language prescriptivist then yes lol

author: zkdid
content: thanks thats interesting

author: zkdid
content: ironically it brings me back to my original question where is the agreement?

author: treyzania
content: it's completely social

author: pietjepuk
content: "Persistent scripts" is a more apt description (or so VB said at some point), but welcome to jargon

author: pietjepuk
content: The agreement is social. Some people made clients that decided that that particular contract at that particular address should be listened to for deposits for validators.

author: zkdid
content: So would that not be the EF?

author: pietjepuk
content: The EF is certainly involved in some way, but indeed did not (or rather cannot) make that decision

author: zkdid
content: Yes, I am not going to lie, its really confusing

author: pietjepuk
content: https://medium.com/coinmonks/how-ethereum-governance-works-71856426b63a

author: zkdid
content: I look at decentralisation but just dont understand how high level decisions are made, and then there are contracts etc, people coding them, and I am sat here wondering who I have a contract with, and if I actually have a contract at all?

author: pietjepuk
content: Ethereum is not a company, there's no CEO, no one is in charge, everyone sort of is though, it's all a bit vague (deliberately so)

author: pietjepuk
content: Most smart contracts are just persistent scripts, they have no legal bearing

author: zkdid
content: am i wrong by thinking something is a bit weird about that, with ¬£$350B on the line?

author: pietjepuk
content: Again, it's just what they're historically called

author: pietjepuk
content: Welcome to decentralization

author: paddyl888
content: think of contracts as a sort of vending machine, someone builds it, maintains it and can sometimes take money out of it. but for the regular man on the street you interact with it by going up and putting your money in and then your product plops out.

author: zkdid
content: my mind is a bit blown by it all i must be honest

author: pietjepuk
content: It's definitely very different from your traditional company structure. But even there things mostly have value due to shared beliefs, they're just more formalized

author: pietjepuk
content: There are definitely shades of grey as well in the crypto world, some chains have on-chain governance (google that term, and Vitaliks posts on it). That's a bit like shareholder voting. Other chains have like 10-100 super nodes, which you have to trust.

author: pietjepuk
content: Take a deep dive, it's very weird but very interesting!

author: zkdid
content: its not that they are more formalised its that someone has liability so in the end they cant just keep passing the buck, thats why I am saying the term contract, is contractual!

author: ajsutton
content: It's not going to make you feel any better to learn that the eth2 deposit contract is actually a script that defines that if you send valid inputs, it will take your money and provide no way to ever give it back in any way shape or form.  The fact that the beacon chain uses outputs from that contract to deposit into validator balances is entirely outside of the eth2 deposit contract and not something it specifies at all (the beacon chain spec does).

author: zkdid
content: Hi Adrian, I am guessing you know why I am asking, I am still writing a paper to submit, I hope it is helpful, its difficult talking about sensitive topics publicly, I realise thats the point of decentralisation but how can anyone know who they are talking to. Anyway, I am grateful for everyones input, hope everyone has a nice evening day where ever you are

author: pipermerriam
content: This was a weird, cool, interesting, meandering conversation that I think was valuable to have happened.

author: paddyl888
content: these conversations are important to have because these are the conversations happening any time a member of the general public, not involved with crypto, has when they try and get to grips with it. If we want this technology to become generally accepted then we need to know how to navigate the conversations effectively
